conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, creating a dark region where the light is not reaching.
The size and shape of the shadow depend on the position and distance of the light source relative to the object and the surface where the shadow is cast.
When the light source is high, the shadows are smaller and closer to the objects.
As the light source moves downward, the angle of the light rays relative to the objects and the ground changes.
The shadows will extend further from the objects because the light rays are coming from a lower angle.
As the light source moves downward, the shadows will move away from the objects and appear to stretch out more along the ground.
The shadows will become larger because the light rays are hitting the objects at a more oblique angle, causing the shadows to spread out more.
Shadow A will move away from the object and become larger.
Shadow B will move away from the object and become larger.
Shadow C will move away from the object and become larger.
Shadow D will move away from the object and become larger.
When the light source moves downward, the shadows A, B, C, and D will all move away from their respective objects and increase in size.
The shadows will become longer and more elongated due to the lower angle of the light rays.
The shadows A, B, C, and D will move outward from the objects and increase in size as the light source moves downward.
